Expectation1: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation1: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: I stood at the edge of the crowded room, swirling my drink, when a neighbor approached with a friendly smile. “Hey, I heard you’re working on that big case—what’s it about?” he asked, his tone casual, but his eyes curious. As a lawyer, I knew I couldn’t reveal anything, not even the smallest detail. Client confidentiality was sacred, and my professional ethics demanded absolute discretion. But as a citizen, I felt the pull to engage, to be open and share insights, especially since the case could impact our community. The conversation shifted, and someone mentioned the ballot measure closing soon. I glanced at my watch—barely two hours left to vote. I wanted to discuss the measure, maybe even encourage others to participate, but the specifics of my client’s case were tangled up in the issue. My mind raced, torn between my duty to protect my client and my responsibility to contribute meaningfully as a member of this neighborhood. The weight of both roles pressed on me, and I felt the tension rising as I tried to decide what to say, and what to do next.
